instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1297: What is A1297? A1297 is a model number for a 17 inch size MacBook Pro Unibody from years Early 2009, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011 with EMC 2272, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2390, 820-2610, 820-2849, 820-2914..
definitions.820-2914: What is 820-2914? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.D9701: What is D9701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.LCD_PWR_EN: What is LCD_PWR_EN? LCD_PWR_EN is a signal that tells the chip that supplies power to the LCD screen to turn on..

threads.title: No 5v
threads.message:
Hi all, greetings from the UK... again. Now i am a little lost with this... nothing unusual.
MBP <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1297</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A. Red bull definatly did not give it wiings. Keyboard naffed. Green LED on magsafe. No power. Motherboard surprisingly clean and dry. no corrosion visible across the board even under the scope. The was sticky residue on pins 1-4 of the LVDS connector, cleaned with flux and touched up with new solder. Still no power. Removed the board and started testing the power rails.... this is what I have so far:-
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.57V
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_COMPUTER_ISNS</SIGNAL> 12.57V
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_H3_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> 12.57V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 17.04V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.48V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.323V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> UNABLE TO LOCATE ON THE "NET" COMMAND
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> 0.0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3_ISNS_R</SIGNAL> 0.0V
PP5V-S0 0.0V
and following down the list of power rails becomes obvious the board is devoid of 5v

Now looking at the board view there is listed components in the location UD300 where going by the schematic I have should be 5v points. there is not a single component there. Not unduly worried as there is o solder there either.

Maybe I have gone letter blind but I can seem to find on the schematic the first instance of where 5v feed should be. I have gone away, had a cup of tea, come back and still unable to located where 5v first emerges. Would anyone be king enough to point me to where or what produces the 5v

threads.title: No 5v
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> comes out from pin29/<CHIP>U7201</CHIP> (VREG5).
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> comes out from L7260.
Both require <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> presence.
If none present, chek if pulse at least.

threads.title: No 5v
threads.message: Expect a dead GPU after fixing this one just as a heads up...

threads.title: No 5v
threads.message:
[USER="682"]2informaticos[/USER]  got these readings:-
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5.043V
L7260 = 3.323V
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.476V (STEADY)

[USER="1153"]JohnB8812[/USER] I had a feeling this may be the case but was not sure. After a bit of searching this would seem to be the consensus as to the most common cause of failure.

In both of your opinions is it worth pursuing this? Prices for these boards are commanding £400+ over here.

threads.title: No 5v
threads.message:
You can check at least basic things.
If turns on, can see if GPU has problems...
Check voltage at L7560, or pulse at least.
Be sure to use original Apple 85W charger; it will not turn on with 60W.

threads.title: No 5v
threads.message:
[USER="682"]2informaticos[/USER] see, this is why you get the big bucks for the big jobs.... you hit the nail on the head with the adapter. customer gave me a 60w and swears blind this is what they have been using, used a 85w adapter and powers on. get the chime and an apple logo on the screen but no illumination. with the original screen, I can see lines as though the GPU is failing. Tried a known good screen and although no illumination, shining a torch through the apple logo on the lid there are no green lines. This would indicate either a screen or cable issue.However, I wanted to make sure so I want to get the screen to light up. So again, I have attempted to troubleshoot... and I know I am going to be told I am wrong but here goes.
J9000 pins 2&3 no voltage. Traced back through <CAPACITOR>C9002</CAPACITOR>->L9000-><CAPACITOR>C9001</CAPACITOR>-><CAPACITOR>C9012</CAPACITOR>-><CAPACITOR>C9011</CAPACITOR> to pins 4&5 on  <CHIP>U9000</CHIP>= no voltage. Checked pins 2&3= 3.322v. Pin 1= no voltage. Followed <SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> to <RESISTOR>R9678</RESISTOR>= no voltage. <TRANSISTOR>Q9607</TRANSISTOR> pins 1&4 GND pin 2= 3.317v pin 3= 2.653v pin 5= no voltage pin 6= no voltage. <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> is getting warm but can comfortably leave my finger there without getting burnt ( technical scientific testing there, doesn't burn= not hot...LOL). Other end of J9000 pins 38/39/40= no voltage. at <CAPACITOR>C9008</CAPACITOR> there is no voltage. Tracing <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> at <DIODE>D9701</DIODE> pin 2/ XWD150 pin 1/ <RESISTOR>R9708</RESISTOR> pin 1/ <CAPACITOR>C9717</CAPACITOR> pin 1/ <CAPACITOR>C9716</CAPACITOR> pin 1/ <CAPACITOR>C9718</CAPACITOR> pin 1 all have no voltage. <DIODE>D9701</DIODE> pin 1= no voltage. <CAPACITOR>C9712</CAPACITOR>/13 also have no voltage at pins 1. there is no voltage at L9710. I have looked on boardview and can not locate <RESISTOR>R9700</RESISTOR> but there is a XW9700 which is local to <TRANSISTOR>Q9806</TRANSISTOR>. XW9700 is not on the board. Pins 1/2/5/6 of <TRANSISTOR>Q9806</TRANSISTOR> have no voltage. Pin 4 which goes via a fuse to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is reading 0.800v the same as  on pin 2 of F9800 and pin 1 is 12.57v. Replaced the fuse and instantly popped. 

So in essence, replacement screen and/ or cable required. Keyboard required. Further I go into the board, the more issues I find. Cost of replacement logic board is £400, replacement lid is £250 and keyboard is £15 without labour costs. Replacement <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1297</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> same spec is £550. Even if I buy the replacement and just swap his HDD and charge £50 labour it's going to work out more benificial, especially as there may be further issues along the line. Plus I have told him he will have a spare HDD, RAM and a battery. I think this is the way he will go.

I hate it when something gets the better of me, and I am sure someone better versed at repairing the logic boards will be able to repair quicker, so far I have spent in excess of 4 hrs and still no further.
[USER="682"]2informaticos[/USER] as I have said to you many times before, thanks for your assistance and it is greatly appreciated.
